column1:
third-party-access-to-regasification-terminals-adapting-to-the-lng-markets-recon;;;;World;WORLD;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Third-Party Access to Regasification Terminals: Adapting to the LNG Markets’ Reconfiguration;"

About the Project
KAPSARC is analyzing the shifting dynamics of the global gas markets. Global gas
markets have turned upside down during the past five years: North America has
emerged as a large potential future LNG exporter while gas demand growth has been
slowing down as natural gas gets squeezed between coal and renewables. While the
coming years will witness the fastest LNG export capacity expansion ever seen
questions are raised on the next generation of LNG supply
column2: the impact of low oil and gas

column1: prices on supply and demand patterns and how pricing and contractual structure may
be affected by both the arrival of U.S. LNG on global gas markets and the desire of
Asian buyers for cheaper gas.
Key Points
Substantial changes to global liquefied natural gas (LNG) markets
column2: including the move toward the creation of an Asian trading hub
column3: more flexibility through an increase of spot and short-term trade
column5: emergence of new players and current oversupply
column6: call for better access to existing regasification terminals
column7: which does not hamper the development of new infrastructure.

column1: Around 420 million tons per annum (mtpa) or 54 percent of global regasification capacity offers
column3: some sort of third-party access (TPA). However
column4: this access happens rarely in practice outside of Europe. Many terminals in other regions don’t offer TPA due to a lack of gas market liberalization and control of LNG terminals by incumbents

column1: Access to LNG terminals may prove to be a cornerstone of successful liberalization policies in Asia given the key role of LNG as a source of gas supply.
Regulators could opt for full or partial TPA or to implement an effective secondary market for TPA-exempted terminals to prevent capacity hoarding and minimize contractual congestions.

Access to infrastructure – both pipeline and LNG import capacity – is a key factor for the establishment of a functioning trading hub. This goes hand-in-hand with initiatives to get rid of final destination clauses.

FAO Agricultural Capital Stock Database.

Activity coverage: Agriculture
column9:
fishery (ISIC Rev.3: A+B).

Main indicators: Agricultural Gross Fixed Capital Formation (GFCFAFF)
column10: Agricultural Net and Gross Capital Stock (NCSAFF & GCSAFF)
column12: Agricultural Investment ratio (AIR)
column13:
and the Agriculture Orientation Index in physical investment flows (INV_AOI).

As part of the FAO Agricultural Capital Stock database
column14: ESS-FAO publishes   country-by-country data on annual physical investment flows in agriculture
column15: forestry and fishery as measured by the System of National Accounts (SNA)   concept of Gross Fixed Capital Formation (GFCF).The FAO Capital Stock   Database is an analytical database. For most countries
column16:
published series start in 1990.

Whenever available
column17: the database integrates national accounts data   harvested from UNSD National Accounts Official Country Data (UNSD OCD) or   OECD STAN and OECD Annual National Accounts (OECD ANA). To make data   comparable across countries and over time
column18: national data series have been   rescaled to pair the ISIC Rev. 3 levels (linking of series is done by   applying ratios computed on    overlapping years of data) and re-referenced using the UNSD National   Accounts Estimates of Main Aggregates database. If the full set of national   accounts data on the above-mentioned set of agriculture capital related   variables is not available for a specific country from these sources
column19: estimation procedures are employed to construct complete time series. For a   description of the procedures implemented to obtain complete time series on   GFCFAFF
column22:
see the â€œData Compilationâ€ section underneath.

Country data on Gross Fixed Capital Formation (GFCF) in agriculture
column24: either as complete time series or just data for a few   individual years
column25: are available for just over 100 countries
column26: originating   mainly from the UNSD NA OCD
column27:
and OECD STAN and OECD ANA.

Country data on agricultural Net Capital Stock (NCSAFF)
column28: Gross Capital   Stock (GCSAFF) and Consumption of Fixed Capital (CFCAFF) are available only   for a limited number of countries - to a large extent from OECD countries and   included in the OECD STAN database. For some 20 other countries data are also   availed from the UNSD National Accounts Official Country Data. Data on Gross   Capital Stock (GCS) is available only for a few OECD countries. Based on the   dataset on agriculture GFCF
column30: GCSAFF and CFCAFF series   for all countries for which country data are not available from the above   mentioned sources. To that end
column31: a variation of the perpetual inventory method   is used (for further details
column32:
see â€œData Compilationâ€ section below).



Series are also presented in Constant prices. The total economy GFCF deflators from UNSD National Accounts Estimates have been used for non-OECD countries. As for OECD countries
column33: GFCFAFF specific deflator series in ISIC   Rev.3 A+B are used when available. For other cases
column34: the GFCF-total economy   deflator for GFCF has been used. The same deflators as for GFCFAFF have been   used for GCSAFF

column2:
United Arab Emirates;EMEA;http://www.globalccsinstitute.com/copyright-statement;Public;;;;Mtpa;;Large Scale Carbon Capture Projects Database;"

Data source copyrights: http://www.globalccsinstitute.com/copyright-statement 

Globally
column3: there are 15 large-scale CCS projects in operation
column4:
with a further seven under construction. The 22 projects in operation or under construction represents a doubling since the start of this decade. The total CO2 capture capacity of these 22 projects is around 40 million tonnes per annum (Mtpa).

There are another 10 large-scale CCS projects at the most advanced stage of development planning
column6:
with a total CO2 capture capacity of around 14 Mtpa. A further 12 large-scale CCS projects are in earlier stages of development planning (the Evaluate and Identify stages) and have a total CO2 capture capacity of around 25 Mtpa.

Two large-scale CCS projects became operational in 2015:

  • The Quest project
column8: Canada (CO2 capture capacity of approximately 1 Mtpa) was launched in November 2015. The project
column9: involving the manufacture of hydrogen for upgrading bitumen into synthetic crude oil
column10:
is North America’s first large-scale CCS project to store CO2 exclusively in a deep saline formation.
  • The Uthmaniyah CO2-EOR Demonstration Project
column11:
located in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia was launched in July 2015. The project is capable of capturing around 0.8 Mtpa of CO2 from the Hayiwah NGL (natural gas liquids) Recovery Plant.

Two more industrial CCS projects are expected to become operational in early 2016:

  • The Illinois Industrial CCS Project (CO2 capture capacity of 1 Mtpa) is located at the Archer Daniel Midlands corn-to-ethanol production facility in Decatur
column12: Illinois (United States).  The project
column13: the world’s first bio-CCS project at large scale
column14:
will be the first integrated CCS project in the United States to inject CO2 into a deep saline formation at a scale of 1 Mtpa.
  • The Abu Dhabi CCS Project (CO2 capture capacity of 0.8 Mtpa)
column15: the world’s first iron and steel project to apply CCS at large scale
column16:
will involve CO2capture from the direct reduced iron process used at the Emirates Steel plant in Abu Dhabi.

Large-scale CCS projects in the power sector are now a reality
column17:
demonstrated by:

  • The world’s first large-scale power sector CCS project – the Boundary Dam Carbon Capture and Storage Project in Canada (CO2 capture capacity of 1 Mtpa) – becoming operational in October 2014.
  • Commissioning activities on a new-build 582 megawatt (MW) power plant beginning at the Kemper County Energy Facility in Mississippi (United States
column18:
CO2 capture capacity of 3 Mtpa) with CO2 capture expected to commence around the middle of 2016.
  • The Petra Nova Carbon Capture Project at the W.A. Parish power plant near Houston
column19: Texas (US
column20: CO2 capture capacity of 1.4 Mtpa) entering construction in July 2014
column21:
with CO2 capture anticipated by the end of 2016.

Definitions of what constitutes a large-scale integrated project and of the various stages in the lifecycle of a project are found at: http://www.globalccsinstitute.com/projects/large-scale-ccs-projects-definitions

  • Citation: ""Large Scale CCS Projects | Global Carbon Capture And Storage Institute"". Globalccsinstitute.com. N.p.

column1:
solor-pv-dataset;2018-10-10;;;World;WORLD;https://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;World Solar Photovoltaic Regional Costs;"

Solar Photovoltaic Dataset

The solar industry has witnessed remarkable declines in of costs during the past 25 years for a number of reasons including technological advancements and industry expansion. The benchmark component that is typically referred to when reporting cost trends is the solar module and many institutions publish the global average selling price for the modules on a regular basis.

Indeed
column2: the module price serves as a good indicator of developments in the solar industry and technology. However
column3: the module price is unable to capture regional differences that arise when building solar PV systems. Variations in labor costs
column5: taxes and cost of capital between countries are some of the reasons why the same plant would have very different costs when built in different places. The same also applies to the levelized cost of energy; solar conditions as well as maintenance costs vary across countries
column6:
which result in different operational costs. The variations in capital expenditure and operational costs between countries become even more pronounced when considering the size of the installed system.

To capture regional differences in capital and generation costs
column7: we have compiled a large collection of data across many geographies for the three typical system sizes (i.e. residential
column9: and utility). The costs are provided and accompanied by the assumptions that were used to arrive at these actual costs including interest rates
column12: etc
column13:
where these assumptions are given in the source.

This dataset was used to build our interactive tool published on website https://www.kapsarc.org/openkapsarc/kapsarc-solar-photovoltaic-toolkit/  

Users can compare the costs in a variety of ways depending on the filters that are used. For instance
column14: a user can see how generation costs change if the financial assumptions are altered. For this reason
column15: the Toolkit provides an excel-based Analyzing Tool to aid in experimenting and evaluating different scenarios. The raw data is also provided if a user is interested in performing further analysis. To summarize
column16:
this tool kit provides the following:

1.A spatial (map-based) interactive representation of CAPEX

2.A spatial (map-based) interactive representation of LCOE

3.A scatter chart interactive representation of CAPEX

4.A scatter chart interactive representation of LCOE

5.An interactive bar chart for annual global solar PV installations

6.An interactive bar chart for cumulative global solar PV installations

7.An LCOE Analyzer that attains the LCOE via capacity factor or solar irradiation

column1:
will-current-electric-vehicle-policy-lead-to-cost-effective-electrification;;;;World;WORLD;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Will Current Electric Vehicle Policy Lead to Cost-Effective Electrification?;"

About the Project
After decades of development and false starts
column2: electric vehicles have now become commercial. However
column3: they still rely on strong policy support for their further development and adoption.

column1: The project assesses the effectiveness of current electric vehicle policy in leading the technology toward self sustained market competitiveness. The multi-method approach chosen involves techno-economic
column2: strategy and innovation systems analysis. In particular
column3: we have developed a bottom-up electric vehicle fleet cost model in order to assess the economic implications of electric vehicle policy

column1: Key Points

Passenger cars are responsible for a large and steadily growing share of global energy-related greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Electric vehicles (EVs) powered by renewable electricity have the potential to provide a substantial contribution to the decarbonization of passenger car transport. Unless carbon capture and storage technologies become cost competitive
column2: EVs are likely to form a growing share of the personal mobility solution. But what is the lowest cost path to achieving high levels of EV penetration?

column1: Encouraged by the falling cost of batteries
column2: EV policy today focuses on expediting electrification
column3: paying comparatively little attention to the cost of the particular type of EVs and charging infrastructure being deployed. This paper argues that
column4: due to its strong influence on EV innovation paths
column5: EV policy could be better designed if it paid more attention to future cost and technology development risk. In particular

column1: EV policy with a strong bias toward long-range battery electric vehicles (BEVs) risks leading to a higher cost of electrification in the 2030 timeframe
column2: possibly exceeding the ability of governments to sustain the necessary incentives until battery cost drops sufficiently.

column1: Plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs) with long electric range could allow intermediate decarbonization targets to be met while being less sensitive to the rate of development of battery technology. The BEV option could be pursued in parallel by targeting specific segments where shorter ranges are acceptable to their users.
Promoting a balanced mix of BEVs and PHEVs could set the electrification of passenger cars on a lower risk
column3: path that is more likely to become self-sustained before government support is withdrawn.

column1: Examining EV policy in the U.K. and in California
column2: we find that it is generally not incompatible with achieving balanced mixes of BEVs and PHEVs. However
column3:
this may not be sufficient and some fine tuning would enable better balancing of medium-term risks and long-term goals.

";KAPSARC Publications;Discussion paper

column1:
kapsarc-vehicle-fleet-model-cost-of-electrification;;;;World;WORLD;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;KAPSARC Vehicle Fleet Model: Cost of Electrification;"

About the Project
After decades of development and false starts
column2: electric vehicles have now become commercial. However
column3: they still rely on strong policy support for their further development and adoption.

column1: The project assesses the effectiveness of current electric vehicle policy in leading the technology toward self sustained market competitiveness. The multi-method approach chosen involves techno-economic
column2: strategy and innovation systems analysis. In particular
column3: we have developed a bottom-up electric vehicle fleet cost model in order to assess the economic implications of electric vehicle policy.

column1: Summary
This paper discusses the model we have developed at KAPSARC for estimating the relative costs of passenger car fleets containing low-emission vehicles of different types
column2: particularly with emphasis on electric vehicles. The main purpose of the model is to enable analysis of low-emission vehicle policy; in particular
column3: we have so far applied it to the analysis of the cost implications of supporting different types of EVs and battery charging infrastructures. The model has been designed for simplicity
column4: transparency and ease of use by non-expert stakeholders. As such the approach taken is inspired by metamodelling
column6: : we draw on the results of different existing pieces of techno-economic analysis and we bring them together in a simple modelling framework
column7: which allows for the testing of the highlevel cost implications in a transparent way. The model has also been designed such that it can be easily updated when new evidence becomes available or adapted to analyze different vehicle and infrastructure technologies.

column1: The model calculates the Relative Cost of Ownership (RCO) of individual vehicles
column2: selected as representative of main market segments in the passenger car fleet that is the subject of our study. For each of these vehicles
column3: we model both its internal combustion engine (ICE) version and all main electric powertrain types
column6: range-extended electric (RE-EV) and plug-in hybrid (PHEV). In the case of the electric powertrain vehicles
column7: the user can select the desired battery size and charging infrastructure coverage. The user can then also select fleet penetration levels of each powertrain type by market segment
column8: and the model adds up all the RCO of the individual vehicles over the whole fleet to return the incremental annual cost of passeng

column1: In addition to the total cost of the fleet
column2: the model can also estimate fleet average CO2 emissions
column3: both tailpipe and Well-to-Wheel
column4: and overall infrastructure utilization levels. Analysis of vehicle cost and emissions at segment level is also possible. A quick guide on how to use the simplified version of the model
column5:
which is available online is provided at the end of the paper.

";KAPSARC Publications;Methodology papers

column6:
United Arab Emirates;EMEA;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Economic Stability in the GCC Countries;"

About the Project

column1: The project explores alternative methods of measuring economic diversification and investigating its associated impacts on the Saudi Arabian economy and other GCC countries. By utilizing a financial portfolio framework reconciled with economic growth theory
column2: the economy is viewed as a portfolio of economic sectors
column3: each contributing to the overall output growth. Results demonstrated that diversification policies have been effective
column4: as the economy moves towards higher growth with lower instability.

column1: Key Points
Evidence confirms that there is a positive correlation between the economic growth rate and its volatility/risk in the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) region. In other words
column2: there is a trade-off between the benefits of oil and gas activity and the volatility resulting from unpredictable commodity price swings in such resource dependent economies.

column1: Our analysis uses a financial portfolio framework approach (and more specifically an efficient frontier analysis)
column2: treating economic sectors as individual investments. We calculate a relative risk measure termed the ‘beta coefficient’ and assemble a portfolio of sectors with varying weights to find the efficient frontier. If the beta of the portfolio representing the economy is above global average
column3: the economy will generally grow faster than the global average but with greater volatility – the upturns will be higher and the downturns deeper. We aim to shed light on diversification policy from this novel

column1: The GCC economies exhibit ‘high beta
column2: ’ particularly Qatar. Saudi Arabia sits in the middle of the group
column3: but above the global average
column4: while Oman has the lowest coefficient of the group.

column1: Saudi Arabia’s National Transformation Plan to 2020 and economic Vision 2030 envisage an economy that is still invested in oil and gas activity at 45 percent of total output. While diversification policies in these plans promote economic growth
column2: it still leaves the economy exposed to the volatility of energy markets. In comparison
column3: the optimal mix of economic sectors could increase the growth rate by more than 1 percent annually and nearly halve the expected volatility (to less than 60 percent of growth rate).

column1: Saudi Arabia’s historical economic policies were effective in achieving some diversification. However
column2: their benefits could be increased by policies that balance productive efficiency with diversification of economic activity.

column1:
The difference between policy-optimized portfolio and non-constrained optimization can be used to estimate the size of the fiscal stabilization fund needed to protect the economy from stop/go risks to diversification objectives.

";KAPSARC Publications;Discussion paper

reporting-lcoe-for-solar-pv-apples-to-apples-comparisons;;;;World;WORLD;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Reporting LCOE for Solar PV: Apples to Apples Comparisons;"

About the Project
As solar PV installations continue to grow globally
column2: a better understanding of the generation costs of this industry is important to assess its competitiveness versus conventional generation technologies. Using reported LOCE values for the solar industry
column3: a normalization procedure which levels the playing field between reported values
column4: was applied. The normalization procedure enables performing apples-to-apples comparisons between different projects. Accepting an LCOE figure without being aware of the underlying assumptions can result in erroneous conclusions. With the aid of the normalization exercise carried out in this paper
column5: policymakers and investors are able to make more informed decisions: policymakers can look to formulate well-targeted budgets for renewable support
column6: while investors can envisage a clearer picture of their expected revenues.

column1: Key Points
Solar energy is expected to be an integral technology in the creation of a low-carbon future. Hence
column2: as photovoltaics (PV) installations continue to grow at an exponential rate
column3: a better understanding of the generation costs of this relatively young industry is necessary in order to assess its competitiveness versus conventional sources. Using an extensive dataset of generation costs for solar technology

column1: Despite its inherent shortcomings
column2: the levelized cost of energy (LCOE) is still the de facto metric used by research centers
column3: private sector and government institutions to quantify electricity generation costs.

column1: The LCOE range for solar generation is significantly larger than that for conventional generation. This large spread for solar is mainly attributed to differences on how detailed the calculation of the LCOE is
column2: the use of outdated or inaccurate assumptions
column3: and/or not being explicit about the financial conditions including policy support

column1: To compare different solar LCOEs equitably
column2: we applied a ‘normalization’ procedure. The reported LCOE values were recalculated using numerical inputs stemming from global norms to fill gaps or deal with location-specific artefacts. Normalizing assumptions were applied to all the LCOE data points used in this paper. As expected
column3: the spread decreases considerably

column1: This normalization procedure
column2: which leveled the playing field for reported LCOEs
column3: suggests that the large variation in solar LCOE values that is generally accepted in literature is overstated. Furthermore
column4:
power purchase agreement prices for recent competitive bids should not be confused with LCOE and care is needed when comparing projects to ensure that a ‘new record’ was in fact achieved.

";KAPSARC Publications;Discussion paper

column1: gasoline-demand-pricing-policy-and-social-welfare-in-saudi-arabia0;;;;Saudi Arabia;EMEA;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Gasoline Demand
column2:
Pricing Policy and Social Welfare in Saudi Arabia;"

About the Project

column1: KAPSARC’s projects on energy demand model how factors such as income
column2: prices and energy efficiency influence energy demand in different countries
column3: with a strong focus on Saudi Arabia and the Gulf Cooperation Council. The project’s objective is to quantify the influence of each of these factors and estimate the relative levels of energy efficiency across different sectors of the economy. Our energy demand research also looks at the welfare implications of policies that influence energy demand.

column1: Key Points
In the face of low international oil prices
column2: countries in the Gulf Cooperation Council recently implemented fuel price reform across a number of sectors. Saudi Arabia
column3: for example
column4: announced in December 2015 an increase in the gasoline price. We undertook a welfare analysis in this paper to estimate the net gain in social welfare that resulted from this price increase. Our results show that:

column1: Gasoline demand is generally price inelastic in Saudi Arabia
column2: the current lack of alternative transport modes
column3: particularly within cities
column4: being one possible reason. Our preferred econometric estimates suggest that the price elasticity is between -0.09 and -0.15. Therefore
column5: the gasoline price increase is unlikely to dampen domestic demand significantly.

column1: The gasoline price increase could potentially result in a net gain in social welfare of as much as SAR 2 billion annually at 2010 prices
column2: which is equivalent to 0.1 percent of the Kingdom’s gross domestic product (GDP) in 2015.

column1: These welfare gains do not take into account the external costs of gasoline demand and driving. The gasoline price increase would also offer additional welfare benefits to consumers through reduced greenhouse gas emissions
column3: congestion and accidents.

column1:
The structure of the Saudi labor market and government spending on public employee salaries suggests that the direct loss for consumers due to the price increase would probably be offset by gains for producers (mainly Saudi Aramco) and the government.

";KAPSARC Publications;Discussion paper

human-geography-of-energy-combining-remote-sensing-and-social-science-approaches;;;;World;WORLD;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Human Geography of Energy: Combining Remote Sensing and Social Science Approaches;"

About the Project
This research program seeks to combine remote sensing and social science methods to study energy development
column2: energy use and inform energy policy. This is a novel research program that does not exist at the leading energy research centers in the world. The impact of this research program could yield new and significant insights in how energy is measured and studied. The research team has launched two pilot projects in 2017
column3: with an eye toward expanding KAPSARC’s research into RS3 by the end of 2017 and into 2018. These projects blend remote sensing techniques with social science approaches to understand how energy use and energy development are affecting communities

column1: Key Points

Human Geography of Energy describes a methodology that utilizes remote sensing and social science methods to answer research questions about energy use and energy development. To explore the potential of this approach
column2: KAPSARC organized workshops in London and Boulder
column3: Colorado to work out whether technology and tools had matured sufficiently to execute such a program and deliver policy relevant insights that could not be achieved by alternate means

column1: Such a program would seek to bring together the right combination of remote sensing approaches to measure changes in land use/land cover
column3: population density and settlements.

column1: Social science methods such as household surveys and interviews would be utilized when appropriate to corroborate
column3: or correlate with remote sensing data
column5: ’ yielding more valuable insights than either of the approaches could achieve on its own.

column1: Potential high-impact projects identified include:
<ul>

• Measuring settlement growth and biomass usage in areas with little or no access to formal energy.
  • Tracking the impact of energy development and consumption on communities.
  • Validating data on stockpiles of coal in China and India

understanding-long-term-consumer-demand-for-fuel-efficient-vehicles;;;;World;WORLD;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Understanding Long-Term Consumer Demand for Fuel-Efficient Vehicles;"

About the Project
Promoting adoption of energy-efficient vehicles has become a key policy imperative in both developed and developing countries. Understanding the impact of various factors that affect adoption rates
column2: such as: (i) consumer related factors – demographics
column3: behavioral
column9: network effects; forms the backbone of KAPSARC’s efforts in the transportation field. Our team is currently developing models at different levels of resolution – micro level models using large-scale data comprising of new car buyers’ profiles and macro level models using aggregated adoption data
column10: to understand and project the effects of various factors at play for the adoption of energy-efficient vehicles.

column1: Key Points

Consumer adoption of fuel-efficient vehicles is a crucial step in improving energy use and reducing emissions from the transportation sector. The range of options includes hybridization of powertrains all the way through to fully electric vehicles. To promote adoption
column2: policymakers have employed supply side policies such as the Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Emissions/Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) standards and the Zero Emission Vehicle (ZEV) mandate
column3: which require automakers to produce and sell fuel-efficient and alternative fuel vehicles. In addition
column4: demand side measures in the form of financial and non financial incentives promoting ZEV adoption have also been employed. We measure the changes in consumers’ purchase motivations and potential demand in the wake of such programs by analyzing the past 11 years of new vehicle buyer survey data in the United States as a case study. We find that:

column1: Hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs)
column2: plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs) and battery electric vehicles (BEVs)
column3: collectively termed xEVs
column4: had the potential to secure as much as ~11 percent of the U.S. automotive market in model year 2015
column5: but the actual market share was only one-third of this.

column1: A narrowing of the consumer’s valuation gap between buyers of non xEVs and xEVs for purchase motivations – including fuel economy
column3: technical innovation and price – is increasing the potential consumer demand for xEVs. The term valuation gap refers to the difference between the average rating given by buyers of non xEVs and buyers of xEVs for a particular purchase motivation question in the survey. The closer the ratings
column4: the smaller will be the valuation gap.

column1: Policy instruments such as sales weighted fuel economy target show strong correlation with the consumer valuation gap. In combination with demand side policies that make xEVs more accessible to mainstream consumers
column2:
they could be considered as viable tools if policymakers are seeking to nudge consumers toward xEVs.

gasoline-demand-pricing-policy-and-social-welfare-in-saudi-arabia;2017-04-23;;;Saudi Arabia;EMEA;https://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Gasoline Demand
column2: Pricing Policy and Social Welfare in Saudi Arabia;"

column1: Key Points:
In the face of low international oil prices
column2: countries in the Gulf Cooperation Council recently implemented fuel price reform across a number of sectors. Saudi Arabia
column3: for example
column4:
announced in December 2015 an increase in the gasoline price. We undertook a welfare analysis in this paper to estimate the net gain in social welfare that resulted from this price increase. Our results show that: 

Gasoline demand is generally price inelastic in Saudi Arabia
column5: the current lack of alternative transport modes
column7: being one possible reason. Our preferred econometric estimates suggest that the price elasticity is between -0.09 and -0.15. Therefore
column8:
the gasoline price increase is unlikely to dampen domestic demand significantly. 

The gasoline price increase could potentially result in a net gain in social welfare of as much as SAR 2 billion annually at 2010 prices
column9:
which is equivalent to 0.1 percent of the Kingdom’s gross domestic product (GDP) in 2015. 

These welfare gains do not take into account the external costs of gasoline demand and driving. The gasoline price increase would also offer additional welfare benefits to consumers through reduced greenhouse gas emissions
column11:
congestion and accidents. 

The structure of the Saudi labor market and government spending on public employee salaries suggests that the direct loss for consumers due to the price increase would probably be offset by gains for producers (mainly Saudi Aramco) and the government.

column1: About the Project:
KAPSARC’s projects on energy demand model how factors such as income
column2: prices and energy efficiency influence energy demand in different countries
column3: with a strong focus on Saudi Arabia and the Gulf Cooperation Council. The project’s objective is to quantify the influence of each of these factors and estimate the relative levels of energy efficiency across different sectors of the economy. Our energy demand research also looks at the welfare implications of policies that influence energy demand.

a-measurement-device-for-estimating-local-firm-capabilities-in-new-oil-producing;;;;Uganda;EMEA;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;A Measurement Device for Estimating Local Firm Capabilities in New Oil Producing Countries;"

About the Project
Natural Resource-led Development in New Producing Countries

Our project seeks to understand how natural resource extraction can drive inclusive economic growth in new producing countries. We are engaged in a multiyear multidisciplinary study with four objectives:
<ul>
• Understand the human geography of new producing countries.
• Assess the magnitude of new discoveries and estimate direct fiscal impact.
• Understand how industry can be localized to create economic growth.
• Estimate spillovers and welfare impacts to society.
We recognize that policymaking in new producing countries is a complex process
column2: and our project also seeks to understand the interactions of actors' interests that drive energy sector policies.

column1: Our initial focus is on four countries – Kenya
column3: Tanzania and Uganda – that expect to develop significant oil and gas reserves in the next 5-7 years. Through natural resource development
column4: these countries hope to achieve middle-income economic status by 2030-2040. This project is conducted through close collaboration with leading think tanks and NGOs in Africa

column1: Summary
I n this paper we present an overview of KAPSARC’s local content project
column2: its methodological approach and objective. We describe a measurement device (questionnaire) used to quantify different features of local firms surveyed in Uganda. The data collected in these questionnaires provides essential information to help analyze the current state of local firms in Uganda as they gear up to join the oil and gas supply chain. We also comment on each section of the form explaining its purpose. The questionnaire is attached as part of this document in the Appendix.

column1: The design of the questionnaire allows for a combined approach to examining local firms. On the one hand
column2: it is based on selected basic requirements of the oil and gas industry
column3: which companies must usually fulfill if they aspire to be a supplier. On the other
column4: it also considers the local firms from a dynamic perspective
column5: focusing on their potential to adapt and carve a role in the oil and gas supply chain. This perspective is centered on the concepts of innovation and absorptive capacity
column6: which are increasingly considered when evaluating small and medium enterprises (SMEs) at the firm level.

column1: The questionnaire was designed to be used in faceto-face interviews
column2: which is usually recommended for surveys carried out in Africa. The document is relatively lengthy and is intended to be utilized in developing nations
column3: although a few questions would have to be adapted to the characteristics of each country based on the level of development and exposure to the oil and gas industry.

column1: The questionnaire includes five sections to make it more comprehensible. The data collected is extensive
column2:
allowing for a variety of analytical approaches.

column2:
Roger Tissot and Daniel Mabrey Uganda EMEA http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;A Conceptual Framework for Measuring Local Firm Capabilities in New Producing Countries;"

About the Project

column1: Natural Resource-led Development in New Producing Countries

Our project seeks to understand how natural resource extraction can drive inclusive economic growth in new producing countries. We are engaged in a multiyear multidisciplinary study with four objectives:
<ul>

• Understand the human geography of new producing countries.
  • Assess the magnitude of new discoveries and estimate direct fiscal impact.
  • Understand how industry can be localized to create economic growth.
  • Estimate spillovers and welfare impacts to society.
We recognize that policymaking in new producing countries is a complex process
column2: and our project also seeks to understand the interactions of actors' interests that drive energy sector policies.

column1: Our initial focus is on four countries – Kenya
column3: Tanzania and Uganda – that expect to develop significant oil and gas reserves in the next 5-7 years. Through natural resource development
column4: these countries hope to achieve middle-income economic status by 2030-2040. This project is conducted through close collaboration with leading think tanks and NGOs in Africa.

column1: Key Points

Policymakers in new resource-rich Eastern African countries are eager to promote industrialization and economic development by encouraging international oil and gas companies (IOCs) to use local suppliers. However
column2: policymakers usually lack information on the local firms’ abilities and typically depend on studies by the IOCs to assess these capabilities. Such studies are useful and necessary but they usually only address the needs of the IOCs. By considering the capacity of local firms to learn and innovate
column3: vital information is gathered which can then be used to enhance the design of local content policies. It also raises the prospects for the creation of a more sustainable local supplier base.

column1: The assessment of the capabilities of local firms could be improved by introducing the constructs of absorptive capacity and innovation. This would give policymakers a dynamic
column3: view of the local industry.

column1: Providing policymakers with a better understanding of the local firms’ potential and ability to learn and grow will allow them to come up with more varied options in the design of local content policies and potentially provide more suppliers for industry.

A wider perspective of the local firms’ capabilities also contributes to the linking of local content policies to the overarching objective of expanding the local economy.

data-tables-of-global-and-hemispheric-temperature-anomalies;2017-05-09;;Knoema;World;WORLD;https://www.ornl.gov/ornl/contact-us/Security--Privacy-Notice;Public;;;;;;Data Tables of Global and Hemispheric Temperature Anomalies;

Global and hemispheric temperature anomalies - land and marine instrumental records. These global and hemispheric temperature anomaly time series
column2: which incorporate land and marine data
column3: are continually updated and expanded by P. Jones of the Climatic Research Unit (CRU) with help from colleagues at the CRU and other institutions. The land portion of the database from which the Jones et al. time series are computed consists of surface air temperature (SAT) data (land-surface meteorological data and fixed-position weather ship data) from over 3000 station records that have been corrected for non-climatic errors
column4:
such as station shifts and/or instrument changes (Jones 1994). The marine data used are compiled at the Hadley Centre of the United Kingdom Meteorological Office and consist of sea surface temperatures (SSTs) that incorporate in situ measurements from ships and buoys. The land and marine data components are combined by first interpolating each to the same 5° x 5° latitude/longitude grid boxes. The combined version takes values from each component and weights the grid boxes where both occur (coastlines and islands).

About the Project

column1: The goal of this project is to understand how policy can expedite renewable energy transitions in a cost-effective way
column2: while allowing competitive national industries to develop. In line with this objective
column3: a wide range of policy instruments
column4: designed and implemented to promote renewable energy
column6: the project takes a holistic approach by analyzing how the competitive dynamics between renewable technologies and incumbent technologies evolve.

column1: In addition
column2: the project focuses on how new technologies in distributed energy resources (DER) are transforming customer/provider relationships. Advances in distributed generation technologies and associated cost reductions are providing customers with potentially attractive alternatives to standard electric utility services
column3: perhaps turning them into ‘prosumers’. Utilities around the world are re-evaluating their business models
column4: and regulators are considering multiple market reforms. The project aims to develop analytical tools and techniques to help address the key market
column5: regulatory and energy policy issues in a power sector with high penetration of DER.

column1: Key Points
Global electricity markets are facing substantial changes from both the demand and supply side of the industry. These structural shifts are also affecting Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries
column2: which need to adapt by developing new electricity models. Moving to a new power system will require significant reforms in the Gulf states. These countries may have to transform: state-run companies to private entities
column3: monopolies to competitive markets
column4: fossil fuel generation to a diversified electricity mix and from regulated to liberalized prices.

column1: Renewable energy can be an economical option to diversify a country’s existing electricity mix. Recent tenders for solar photovoltaic (PV) suggest that renewable technology is competitive or
column3: they confirm that renewables can compete successfully under certain conditions.

column1: As the current business model of pricing electricity
column2: which is based on the marginal cost of production
column3: is becoming obsolete
column4: new models must emerge; and one example is the use of markets that value reliability and flexibility of electricity supply.

column1: Electricity reform efforts in the GCC might incorporate three important characteristics. First
column2: a credible economic plan with a rational time schedule to develop the regulations needed to achieve stated objectives. Second
column3: price and subsidy reform to ensure long-term viability. Third
column4: renewable energy to be added to the generation portfolio
column5:
while natural gas can act as the most effective back up to the system.

column1: the-effect-of-ptas-on-energy-trade-from-chinese-exporters-perspectives;;;;China;APAC;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;The Effect of PTAs on Energy Trade from Chinese & Exporters’ Perspectives;"
About the Project

Our goal is to understand the context of China’s energy economy and underlying decisionmaking processes. This understanding will enable the collection of relevant and accurate data both to feed analysis and drive the interpretation of model outputs. The project aims to analyze and assess information to obtain policy relevant insights. Its focus is on investigating the global consequences of changes to energy markets within China and China’s energy policies. In line with KAPSARC’s overall objectives
column2: the aim is to produce policy relevant insights that may assist actors outside China to understand the consequences of decisions taken by actors in China.

column1: Key Points
During periods of supply abundance that lead to lower prices
column2: commodity exporters strive to secure their market share with major importing economies. This paper seeks to cast light on what drives an exporter’s share of Chinese imports of oil
column3: gas and coal – and we find that the strategy behind achieving this goal need not rely on pricing policies alone. China has been promoting a trade agenda that seeks to strengthen economic ties in the Asia-Pacific region and has been extending negotiations aimed at developing relationships worldwide. The country is a major energy import powerhouse; its trade deals have significant impact on the international energy trade and global energy markets. We explore the role of energy in China’s preferential trade agreements (PTAs) and extend the trade gravity model to disaggregated trade flows
column4: estimating the impact these agreements have on Chinese energy imports. We find that: Securing energy/resource imports is not the major driver of China’s PTA strategy. Other considerations include: access to significant or strategically important markets
column5: complementary economic and trade structures and extending political influence. The impact of PTAs on trade patterns varies across product groups. Agreement elements may include tariff reduction
column6: scope and other specific policy arrangements. From China’s perspective

column1: <ul>
<li>Increase the import flows of coal
column2: crude oil and oil products – but not gas – from a partner economy to China.

column1: <li>Help an energy exporter increase its share in Chinese crude oil and oil product imports.
<li>Divert a partner’s exports of crude oil and oil products to China from competing importers.
From an exporter’s perspective
column2: the presence of an operational PTA with China likely:

column1: <ul>
<li>Increases the import flows of gas from a partner economy to China.
<li>Helps an energy exporter increase its share of Chinese imports of coal.
<li>Diverts a partner’s exports of coal and gas to China from other importers.
<li>Does not affect oil exports to China.
The depth and scope of a PTA does not affect the patterns of Chinese energy imports.

column1:
energy-productivity-evaluating-large-scale-building-energy-efficiency-programs-i;;;;Oman;EMEA;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Energy Productivity: Evaluating Large-Scale Building Energy Efficiency Programs in Oman;"

About the Project

Increasing energy productivity holds some of the greatest possibilities for enhancing the welfare countries get out of their energy systems. It also recasts energy efficiency in terms of boosting competitiveness and wealth
column2: more powerfully conveying its profound benefits to society. KAPSARC and UNESCWA have initiated this project to explore the energy productivity potential of the Arab region
column3: starting with the six GCC countries and later extending to other countries. Aimed at policymakers
column4: this project highlights the social gains from energy productivity investments
column6: and pathways to achieving improved performance in this area.

column1: Key Points
More than 75 percent of the total electricity consumed in Oman is attributed to buildings
column2: with almost 50 percent used by households. The absence of mandatory energy efficiency regulations for buildings
column3: coupled with population growth
column4: has led to a significant increase in annual energy consumption and peak power demand in the country – both averaging growth rates of 10 percent over the last five years. We used an energy productivity analysis approach to analyze the benefits of large-scale energy efficiency programs in new and existing buildings. Our study finds:

column1: Investment in energy efficiency measures to retrofit existing buildings could lead to significant economic and environmental benefits. The potential for energy savings will vary depending on implementation costs and scale of retrofits. The benefits that can be realized for residential buildings are significantly higher than those obtained for commercial or governmental buildings.
If a minimal Level-1 energy retrofit program is applied to existing residential buildings
column2: savings of 957 GWh/year in electricity consumption and 214 MW in peak power demand can be achieved. Moreover
column3: if a Level-3 deep retrofit of energy efficiency measures is implemented for the residential sector
column6: 300 MW in peak power demand. Also
column7: 4 million metric tonnes per year of carbon emissions will be eliminated.

column1: A Level-3 retrofit of the entire building stock in Oman can result in savings of 10
column3: 300 MW in peak power demand. Additionally
column4: there would be a 7 million metric tonnes per year of reduction in carbon emissions

column1:
The economic impact of the buildings' energy efficiency retrofit program is the potential to create new employment in Oman. The direct effects for retrofitting buildings include jobs needed to implement energy efficiency measures while the indirect effects are associated with work needed to produce and supply energy efficiency equipment and materials.

column1: toward-the-integration-of-policymaking-models-economic-models;;;;World;EMEA;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Toward the Integration of Policymaking Models & Economic Models;"
About the Project
KAPSARC is developing the KAPSARC Toolkit for Behavioral Analysis (KTAB)
column3: to support modeling and analysis of collective decisionmaking processes (CDMPs). KTAB is intended to be the standard platform for analyzing bargaining problems
column5: and policy decision-making. It is our intent to use KTAB to assemble the building blocks for a broad class of CDMPs. Typical models in KTAB will draw on the insights of subject matter experts regarding decision makers and influencers in a methodical
column6: consistent manner; and then assist researchers to identify feasible outcomes that are the result of CDMPs.

column1: Summary

The traditional economic approach to policy analysis is to utilize tools and methods developed within the field of economics and study the economic impact of one or more policies solely from an economic perspective. As a consequence
column2: the “policies” are usually formulated and evaluated only by an assessment of the pure economic optimality of expected outcomes. Moreover
column3: economic models typically treat policy choices as exogenously specified. Once policies are selected according to some exogenous process
column4: then scenario analysis can be performed to simulate the economic impact of those policies.

column1: On the other hand
column2: explicit research into the policymaking process – and in particular models of the policymaking process
column3: tend to oversimplify or ignore the economic outcomes of the policies debated among policymakers. In particular
column4: modelers of what we broadly classify as collective decision making processes (CDMPs) – in other words
column5: models that capture the process of political choice – tend to utilize simple
column7: if any economic consideration is taken into account at all. The economic consequences
column9: of choices of actors are generally treated as the end points of models. The implications of policy choices

column1: Either approach in isolation misses out on important interactions between political and economic phenomena. The economically optimal policy is rarely the option selected
column2: and is often not even under consideration because of political considerations. Policies that may appear to be politically appealing at first blush can lose their charm once adopted
column3: because of the economic impact upon attempts to implement them. In this paper
column4: we argue that politics and economics are inextricably intertwined
column5: and can be modeled as such. We develop a hybrid quantitative model of economics and CDMPs that allows us to capture the process of policymaking based on utilities derived from an endogenous economic model.

column1: We develop this model with the KAPSARC Toolkit
for Behavioral Analysis (KTAB)
source platform for building CDMP models. All
KTAB models represent stochastic decision-making
among comparatively small numbers of actors or
stakeholder groups – more than one
hundreds – within the paradigm of Probabilistic
Condorcet Elections (PCE). Even in formal voting
situations
column2: such as in government or boardrooms

column1: informal influence-based negotiation is truly what
drives voting – an obvious example of this is
lobbyists influencing U.S. senators – so we need a
negotiation model that captures this behavior. The
PCE is a general framework for modeling this type
of informal policymaking process; this framework is
extremely flexible
present in others.
In this paper
column3: we develop a CDMP based on the PCE
column4: in which actors represent sectors in a Leontief economy. Each actor negotiates and forms coalitions so as to maximize its (the actor’s) utility. The data we used are synthesized from real data representing nine sectors and three actors of production in the U.S. economy from 1981. Applied to these data
column5: our model demonstrates that strategically sophisticated economic policies can be generated using an integrated CDMP framework.

column1: joint-oil-stockpiling-between-me-exporters-nea-importers;;;;World;WORLD;https://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Joint Oil Stockpiling between ME Exporters & NEA Importers;"

About the Project

Since the oil price shocks of the 1970s
column2: the security of oil supply has been the main concern in academic and policy circles. The goal of this research project is to study the other side of the coin — the security of oil demand from the net-exporters perspective. How do large oil exporters trade off risk and rewards in ensuring security of demand? In the first phase of this research project
column3:
a comparative static model of global oil trade is developed to empirically measure the impacts of alternative crude oil market shares across segmented markets; to assess the strategic choice NOCs have in valuing alternative sales market portfolios in the context of the trade-off along the risk-reward frontier; and to compare IOC behavior as a benchmark for NOCs.

More specifically
column4: this project will attempt to specify a parsimonious model of regionally segmented global oil trade calibrated to 2012 benchmark data which would allow comparative static exercises to simulate equilibrium impacts of alternative placement of term-contracted crude oil
column5: including impacts on total revenues for crude oil producers. The model focuses on three fundamental variables that determine relative crude oil prices: transport costs
column7:
and refinery flexibility

In line with KAPSARC’s overall objectives
column8:
the intent is to produce policy-relevant insights that help actors in the oil industry understand the consequences of decisions taken by large exporters.

The workshop series fits into the overall project by providing a continuing dialogue that raises key issues
column10: and sets future directions. The workshops are an open collaborative forum that enables the discussion of particular themes that feed into identified research questions.

column1:
Key Points

When oil owned and commercially traded by an exporting country is stored in an importing country in exchange for first drawing rights by the host country in times of emergency
column2: that process is known as ‘joint oil stockpiling’. It can thus be classified as both commercial and strategic storage
column3: offering benefits to both parties. The first Middle East (ME)–Northeast Asia (NEA) joint stockpiling deal was concluded in 2006 between Kuwait and South Korea. Since then there have been several similar agreements by which the national oil companies (NOCs) of Saudi Arabia
column4: Kuwait and the UAE have stored crude in in South Korea and Japan. An accord between the UAE and India
column6:
is the most recent example

The unique character of the joint oil stockpiling agreements between ME exporters and the NEA importers means these can meet two objectives simultaneously:

column1: <li>The perceived energy security needs of net oil-importing countries and their objectives of enhancing their respective strategic petroleum reserves at low cost. This is because the oil-importing country does not purchase crude oil up front
column2:
but retains the pre-emptive right to purchase the oil in case of an oil disruption emergency.
  • By obtaining free or cheap storage facilities within close proximity to large consuming countries
column3: ME NOCs can take advantage of the flexibility provided by effectively having short-haul crude on offer to both their term contract clients and to other crude oil refiners that are not term clients. Joint oil stockpiling offers a platform for opportunistic access of Asian spot markets
column4:
an important consideration for the ME NOCs in the current low oil price environment.

Assuming a crude oil price of around $40/barrel (bbl)
column5: 5 percent interest cost of carry and an equal division of the carrying cost savings with the host government
column6:
the ME NOC could gain $9 to $18 million a year if it enjoyed 50 percent of the cost savings in storing 15-30 million barrels (MMbbl).

The host NEA country saves about $2.00/bbl in carrying costs while retaining the pre-emptive right to buy the stored oil during oil supply emergencies. If 15-30 MMbbl are stored
column7:
the NEA country would save an estimated $31.5 million to $63 million per year

column1:
support-for-a-carbon-tax-in-china-a-cdmp-simulation-using-ktab;;;;China;APAC;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Restructuring Saudi Arabiaâ€™s Power Generation Sector: Model-Based Insights;"

About the Project
KAPSARC is developing the KAPSARC Toolkit for Behavioral Analysis (KTAB)
column3: to support modeling and analysis of collective decisionmaking processes (CDMPs). KTAB is intended to be the standard platform for analyzing bargaining problems
column4: generalized voting models and policy decision-making. It is our intent to use KTAB to assemble the building blocks for a broad class of CDMPs. Typical models in KTAB will draw on the insights of subject matter experts regarding decision makers and influencers in a methodical
column5: consistent manner; and then assist researchers to identify feasible outcomes that are the result of CDMPs.

column1: Key Points
China
column2: the world’s largest emitter of carbon dioxide
column3: is taking steps to combat the effects of climate change on its environment. The path it takes to mitigate the effects of pollution will have a significant impact on the global carbon reduction agenda. In this study
column4: we focus on the political feasibility of implementing a carbon tax in China within the next five years. We do this using the KAPSARC Toolkit for Behavioral Analysis (KTAB) platform
column5: a model of collective decision-making processes (CDMPs) developed at KAPSARC to assess the expected support in China for
column7: this potential policy choice. Our key findings are as follows:

column1: The majority of Chinese actors are expected to view as positive the application of a weak carbon tax. A tough
column2: clearly articulated and enforceable carbon tax
column3: however
column4: does not appear to be politically feasible in the current Chinese context.

column1: Large energy companies
column3: may oppose the principle of a carbon tax
column4: but recognize the need to engage in the policy discussion to help shape any potential outcome.

column1: Momentum behind a carbon tax in China is slow but steady. Even if energy companies have substantial political clout and are able to disrupt progress on a carbon tax
column2:
this would not be sufficient to derail the weak but growing consensus that favors some form of tax on carbon.

economic-environmental-benefits-of-improving-uae-building-stock-energy-efficienc;;;;United Arab Emirates;EMEA;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;;;;;;;Economic & Environmental Benefits of Improving UAE Building Stock Energy Efficiency;"

About the Project

Increasing energy productivity holds some of the greatest possibilities for enhancing the welfare countries get out of their energy systems. It also recasts energy efficiency in terms of boosting competitiveness and wealth
column2: more powerfully conveying its profound benefits to society. KAPSARC and UNESCWA have initiated this project to explore the energy productivity potential of the Arab region
column3: starting with the six GCC countries and later extending to other countries. Aimed at policymakers
column4: this project highlights the social gains from energy productivity investments
column6: and pathways to achieving improved performance in this area.

column1: Key Points
In the United Arab Emirates (UAE)
column2: buildings consume almost 90 percent of the total electricity used in the country
column3: mostly in Dubai and Abu Dhabi. We undertook a study to explore available opportunities to improve the energy efficiency of the UAE building sector. This paper assesses the best combinations of energy efficiency measures that can be adopted at a minimal cost. In our simulation
column4: we evaluated a series of energy efficiency options for both existing and new buildings. Our optimization analysis is based on the sequential search technique
column5: applied to a wide range of applications
column6: including combinations of energy efficient measures (EEMs) and retrofitting existing buildings. Our findings are:

column1: Any level of energy efficiency retrofit to existing UAE building stock would achieve significant savings. It is estimated that deep retrofits have the potential to reduce the energy consumption of existing buildings by up to 50 percent.
It is estimated that a basic energy retrofit program applied to existing UAE building stock could achieve savings of 7
column4: 400 MW in peak electricity demand and reduce carbon emissions by 4.5 million tons/year. The scheme would have an average payback period of less than six months for the UAE government.

column1: Our optimization analyses reveal that deployment of a large-scale energy retrofit program for the UAE building stock would be cost-effective for the government. A deep retrofit of the entire building stock would have a payback period of just 2.3 years
column3: 200 GWh/ year in electricity consumption together with 8
column4: 802 MW in peak power demand and reducing 28.5 million tons/year of carbon emissions.

column1: Realizing this value
column2: Dubai has already created a super ESCO (Etihad Energy Services) to finance and jump-start retrofit projects of existing buildings using the performance contracting concept
column3: a means of financing energy efficiency investments that is based on future savings. In March 2017
column4:
the Abu Dhabi Water and Electricity Authority and the UAE Ministry of Economy launched an ESCO in Abu Dhabi. This scheme could be extended to the other emirates.

curbing-carbon-emission-is-a-carbon-tax-the-most-efficient-levy;;;;World;WORLD;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Curbing Carbon Emission: Is a Carbon Tax the Most Efficient Levy;"

About the Project

The objective of this research is to understand how different policy tools could expedite the transition toward a low-carbon economy in a cost-effective manner. This project takes a pragmatic approach to climate change policies
column2: recognizing the need to balance the economic and environmental impacts of these policies. Ignoring the cost of these policies could not only create a substantial economic burden but also lead to a loss of social mandate. This is one of the greatest risks to the successful implementation of sound climate change policy
column3: which by its nature requires clear and predictable government commitment over the long-term.

column1: Key Points
The ambitious environmental objectives of the Paris Agreement imply that
column2: in order to curb carbon emissions
column3: all cost-effective policy options should be considered. These options include carbon taxes
column4: probably the most popular fiscal tool for curbing emissions
column5: and various other taxes on fossil fuels. This study uses Spanish data to assess what are the optimal taxes on oil
column6: natural gas and coal from a welfare perspective
column7: and compares them with a carbon tax in a general equilibrium context. The results of the analysis are as follows:

column1: Among their options for reducing CO2 emissions
column2: policymakers may consider taxing coal heavily. Less punitive taxation of oil and natural gas could also form part of an optimal strategy.

column1: For maximum effectiveness
column2: we found that any planned tax on oil should always be lower than the tax on natural gas
column3: and still lower than that on coal. This counterintuitive result comes about because oil has the highest marginal economic productivity of the three fuels
column4: though natural gas is the cleanest fossil fuel in terms of CO2 emissions. According to standard economic theory
column5: the marginal economic productivity of any fossil fuel should be similar to international prices for it in competitive markets.

column1: Carbon tax has both advantages and disadvantages for policymakers. In the short run
column2: the revenue collected would be higher from an optimal mixture of taxes on the various fossil fuels – but
column3: in the longer term
column4:
higher taxes might be seen by taxpayers as unreasonable and could result in a loss of support for the environmental policies they are intended to underpin.

estimating-the-learning-curve-of-solar-pv-balance-of-systems-for-over-20-countri;;;;World;WORLD;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Estimating the Learning Curve of Solar PV Balance-of-Systems for Over 20 Countries;"

About the Project
Although the costs of solar modules have fallen precipitously and have
column3: followed an 80% learning curve
column4: balance-of-system (BOS) costs have not declined at the same rate. Today
column5: the BOS represents the majority of the capital costs for solar installations. The growing share of BOS in the total cost of solar systems has direct implications on its competitiveness.

column1: For the first time
column2: and with the aid of an extensive dataset
column3: learning curves of the BOS component for residential systems have been deduced for over 20 countries. In addition to computing a global average for BOS learning at 89%
column4: this modeling exercise showed that there are a number of cost reduction opportunities that exist in the BOS segment
column5: and these require no (or little) financial policy support.

column1: Key Points

The capital cost of a solar photovoltaic (PV) system comprises the module and balance-of-systems (BOS). The latter refers to everything else that is needed to make the solar system functional including cables
column3: labor
column4: etc. While modules are priced internationally
column5: the BOS is countryspecific. Price developments of modules
column6: which have been thoroughly studied in literature

column1: The LC for BOS in residential PV systems is estimated for more than 20 countries via an extensive dataset. We show that the BOS LCs for these countries are typically lower than that of modules
column2: affirming the few single-country studies reported previously.

column1: Our calculations yielded a global LC for the BOS of 89 percent
column2: which corresponds to a progress ratio of 11 percent compared with 20 percent for modules.

column1: The data was then divided into two periods – pre- and post-2008 – to study the effects of the global financial crisis on LC development. It was found that many countries were able to sustain progress in the LC post-2008 despite reduced financial policy support
column2:
indicating that there are effective steps that could be taken by policymakers to reduce BOS costs without requiring (significant) financial policy support.

impact-of-domestic-fuel-price-reforms-on-the-use-of-public-transport-in-saudi-ar;;;;Saudi Arabia;EMEA;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Impact of Domestic Fuel Price Reforms on the Use of Public Transport in Saudi Arabia;"

About the Project

We developed the KAPSARC Energy Model for Saudi Arabia (KEM-SA) to understand the dynamics of the country’s energy system. It is a partial equilibrium model formulated as a mixed complementarity problem to capture the administered prices that permeate the local economy. KEM-SA has been previously used to study the impacts of various industrial fuel pricing policies and improved residential efficiency on the energy economy. The passenger transportation model presented in this paper helps understand more of the end-use energy demand.

Key Points

In 2016
column2: policymakers in Saudi Arabia increased domestic transportation fuel prices
column3: which are expected to approach market levels in the near future. Current low crude oil prices offer an excellent opportunity for policymakers to deregulate the passenger transportation sector without a significant change in local fuel prices. We developed a bottom-up transportation sub-model and integrated it with the KAPSARC Energy Model (KEM) to assess whether consumers could afford such reforms; and the resulting travel mode choices
column4: energy consumption levels and revenue. We do not consider price-induced efficiency improvements; hence
column5:
the results would represent an upper bound for the shift to public modes.

Despite a deregulation of the passenger transportation sector
column6:
Saudi households would continue to allocate one of the lowest transport budgets (as a percentage of income) in Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries and also stay within Saudi Arabian historical boundaries.

Deregulating fuel prices would encourage consumers to travel by more efficient public transport modes
column7: as they become available in the near future
column8:
leading to significant energy savings and CO2 emissions reductions of between 4 million to 26 million metric tons (mt) per year.

The Kingdom would receive an annual average $8.2 billion as additional revenue from domestic sales and exports in the varying crude price scenario and $5 billion in the fixed $60/bbl scenario.

Despite the increase in transport fuel price
column9:
the net gain for Saudi Arabia in the varying crude oil price scenario remains positive as a result of substantial increase in revenue and the introduction of more convenient public travel modes.

Our findings show that analyzing energy policies using empirical estimates are generally valid even for large variations in price; however
column10: if new transport modes and technologies are introduced in Saudi Arabia
column11: consumer response may be slightly greater than that of empirical estimate
column12:
which did not account for such new modes.

an-evaluation-of-high-energy-performance-residential-buildings-in-bahrain;;;;Bahrain;EMEA;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;An Evaluation of High Energy Performance Residential Buildings in Bahrain;"

About the Project

Increasing energy productivity holds some of the greatest possibilities for enhancing the welfare countries get out of their energy systems. It also recasts energy efficiency in terms of boosting competitiveness and wealth
column2: more powerfully conveying its profound benefits to society. KAPSARC and UNESCWA have initiated this project to explore the energy productivity potential of the Arab region
column3: starting with the six GCC countries and later extending to other countries. Aimed at policymakers
column4: this project highlights the social gains from energy productivity investments
column6: and pathways to achieving improved performance in this area.

column1: Key Points

This paper describes our analysis of the cost-effectiveness of designing and retrofitting residential buildings in Bahrain and outlines our analytical approach. The study focuses on residential buildings since households consume more than 48 percent of electricity used in the country. As expected
column2: residential buildings constitute the vast majority of Bahrain’s building stock
column3: with about 76 percent of the total and projected annual growth in energy consumption of around 3 percent in the next few years.

column1: The optimization analysis outlined in this paper assesses the potential benefits from retrofitting both individual buildings and the entire national building stock
column2: as well as the benefits of applying proven measures and technologies to improve the energy efficiency of the building sector. Our conclusions are:

column1: The development and enforcement of a more stringent energy efficiency code can potentially improve the energy efficiency of the new building stock with a reduction of more than 320 GWh in annual electricity consumption and 87 MW in peak demand.
Retrofitting the existing building stock in Bahrain has the potential to cost-effectively reduce energy consumption in the building sector by 62 percent
column2: with a 55 percent reduction in peak electricity demand compared with the business as usual scenario. The avoided costs of building new power plants would be sufficient to offset the implementation costs for a basic level of energy retrofitting of existing residential buildings.

column1: We estimate that as much as 31
column2: 700 job-years of employment can be created when retrofitting the existing building stock. More than 3
column3:
000 jobs would be needed annually in order to retrofit existing buildings over a 10-year period.

drivers-of-transportation-fuel-demand-fuel-efficient-mobility-from-the-consumers;;;;World;WORLD;http://www.kapsarc.org/terms-conditions/;Public;;;;;;Economic Cycles and the Responsiveness of Natural Gas Demand in Chinaâ€™s Residential Sector;"

About the Project
The workshop series Drivers of Transportation Fuel Demand provides a forum for discussing key sustainability issues in transportation and current policy strategies to address them. In particular
column2: much emphasis is placed on the adoption of fuelefficient and alternative-fuel vehicles for road transportation
column3: innovation in fuel and vehicle technology mixes and the shift from road to other modes of transportation.

column1: Key Points

The working assumption of most policymakers and automakers is that light-duty vehicle buyers either undervalue fuel economy or behave as if they do – perhaps because of the complexity in evaluating discounted fuel cost savings. If one accepts this argument then huge benefits can be gained from public policies that mandate fuel-efficient mobility through performance standards.
Increasing vehicle fuel economy at the expense of performance has an opportunity cost for consumers as they value performance more than fuel economy. However
column2: it remains an open question as to whether public policy
column3: such as fuel economy standards
column4: should incorporate opportunity costs arising from consumers’ tendency to maximize personal over societal benefit.

column1: Consumer concerns over the adoption of high fuel economy plug-in electric vehicle (PEV) centers around driving range
column3: charging infrastructure
column4: value for money and highway performance
column5: which continue to be major barriers. Evidence suggests that awareness and knowledge about PEVs have not yet increased substantially in many consumer segments. Finding better ways for consumers to gain firsthand experience with PEVs may help overcome this knowledge shortfall.

column1: Short-term incentives to induce PEV sales are expensive; more than $50
column2: 000 per incremental vehicle sold according to some estimates. There is scope to improve cost-effectiveness by developing a targeted incentive structure. Alternatively
column3: devoting resources to technology development rather than deployment might represent a more cost-effective policy approach.

column1: Shared use of automated electric vehicles represents one possible path for achieving deep decarbonization
column2: but its cost-effectiveness versus alternative paths has yet to be confirmed. PEVs seem unlikely to succeed if they are just a decarbonized replacement for today’s vehicles
column3:
but this can be achieved if they provide a better customer experience at a lower price point.
